Value.Value: Land subsidence is the gradual settling or sudden sinking of the Earth’s surface, due to underground material movement. It is often caused by the removal of water, oil, natural gas or mineral resources out of the ground by pumping, fracking, or mining activities. Last but not least, it can also be caused by natural phenomena, such as earthquakes, soil compaction, glacial isostatic adjustment etc. (What Is Subsidence?, n.d.) Subsidence in the Netherlands: Urban areas like Rotterdam, Gouda and Utrecht are sinking as they were built on weak soil as well (Kennislink, 2014). Additionally, the soil in Amsterdam is very soft and buildings are created on stones that have a wooden foundation underneath. The main cause of the rotting of the poles is because of the groundwater level getting lower This can happen due to leaky, draining sewers, drains that are set too low, lowering the surface water, drainage and construction pits. (pg.5 guide KCAF) This means the wood can age, deteriorate or even mould over the years and lead to subsidence which can be saved by fixing the foundation (City of Amsterdam, n.d.). Common visible effects of subsidence • Large cracks in a wall, usually around a door or window frame, which are wider at the top than they are at the bottom. • These cracks are usually more than 3mm wide. • Cracks in the pavement/walls outside. • Doors and windows sticking • Sloping floors - this is common in older properties • If you have an extension, look for cracks where the extension meets the main part of the house.

From signalling to tackling foundation problems These are the 8 steps, the KCAF follows to get to the root of the problem and help anyone struggling with this problem. It explains step by step what should be done and what to expect. If you suspect these problems might affect your living accommodation, we would advise you to follow this guide and take action. 1. Research local archives The first step is going to the town hall to research your location and building and get the necessary data on additional changes that could have been made over the years. 2. Consultation of co-owners of the building If there is no information to be found in the town hall archives, the next step would be to get into contact with previous owners and discuss options with other people that share the building (semi detached houses, or terraced houses). 3. Request help from professionals Hire a professional (council, engineering, guidance office or structural engineer, KCAF) to take a look at the situation. 4. Foundation research Depending on the previous points outcome there might be a need for soil and foundation research. 5. Recover groundwater levels When the foundation is okay as a result of the previous research, the only problem is the soil. Then they will try to rehydrate the soil. 6. Foundation recovery When the aforementioned research shows that the foundation is not okay, they will be looking for different kinds of solutions under supervision regarding safety. 7. The execution of the solution • They will look if the solution will work with the surrounding foundations. • Start construction. • An invoice has been drawn up and confirmed in advance. 8. The Fuselage It is advised by the KCAF to wait at least half a year to restore the visible damage the problems have caused to the house.

KCAF (Knowledge Center Approach Foundation Problems) is located in Utrecht and Nieuwegein and is an independent knowledge and network non-profit organization which takes care of collecting, developing and providing knowledge about the approach and prevention of foundation problems. Its aim is to raise awareness of foundation problems and to expand the aforementioned information by conducting research. Furthermore, KCAF maps out which houses are at risk now and which ones might be in the future. To achieve these, the organization works closely with other knowledge centres, schools, commercial parties and scientific institutes, in order to gain more insights on the problem. Soilmates studios is a group of 7 students from Saxion University of Applied Sciences. Lena Van, Dominique de Graaff, Rania Zouganeli, Julien Trübiger, Els Krajenbrink, Danny van Duist and Niek Tempert are designers, artists and engineers, who worked together to bring KCAF’s idea to life.

What types of foundations are there? • Foundation on steel . • Foundation on wooden poles. Which agency can perform foundation research well and how does this work? • It is important that you approach agencies that work according to the so-called F3O guideline. • It is advised to request an appraisal from multiple agencies. • If you have received the appraisals and then have unanswered questions, we will be happy to provide you with independent advice.
Door de droogte wordt de bodem aangetast en naarmate de grondwaterstanden door de hitte worden verlaagd, wordt ook de fundering aangetast.
The drought will result in soil drying out quickly and as the groundwater levels get reduced by the heat, foundations will be affected too.
